channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: How the E.U. Allowed Hungary to Become an Illiberal Model
item.description: After years of complacency and wishful thinking, Brussels is finally trying to rein in the country’s pugnacious leader, Prime Minister Viktor Orban.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Benjamin Novak
item.media:description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary in June. The position he has put the bloc in says much about why it has stumbled in the face of populist challenges.

item.title: Online ‘Auction’ Is Latest Attack on Muslim Women in India
item.description: The fake site, the second in months, is a sign of the organized nature of virtual bullying, with threats of sexualized violence aimed at silencing the outspoken.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: A Muslim woman walking past an image of Prime Minister Narendra Modi in Kochi, Kerala State, last year.

item.title: How Beijing Has Muted Hong Kong’s Independent Media
item.description: Citizen News, a small but aggressive online publication, is the latest outlet to fold amid relentless pressure from the authorities.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: Stand News Editor Patrick Lam being escorted into a police van in Hong Kong last month.

item.title: Brazil's President, Jair Bolsonaro, Is Hospitalized
item.description: Mr. Bolsonaro, who was stabbed while on the campaign trail in 2018, experienced stomach discomfort during his vacation and was flown back to São Paulo.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño and Flávia Milhorance
item.media:description: President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil in November. The injuries he sustained in 2018 required at least four surgeries.

item.title: South Africa Parliament: Suspect Charged in Fire to Appear in Court
item.description: A 49-year-old man is facing charges of arson and theft in the blaze, which started Sunday and heavily damaged legislative buildings in Cape Town.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Smoke billowing from the Houses of Parliament in Cape Town on Monday.

item.title: Pressure Mounts on Tunisia’s President to Salvage the Economy
item.description: When President Kais Saied seized power in July, he vowed to rescue the failing economy. Tunisians are still waiting for him to fulfill that pledge.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A fish market in Tunis. The price of basic food items is climbing in Tunisia.

item.title: Trump Endorses Viktor Orban, Hungary’s Far-Right Prime Minister
item.description: Democracy in Hungary has been backsliding under Mr. Orban, whose efforts to consolidate power have caused consternation in the European Union.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:description: Viktor Orban, left, was an early supporter of former President Donald J. Trump.

item.title: China Evergrande Suspends Trading Shares in Hong Kong
item.description: The world’s most indebted property developer provided no details on the suspension, but it suggested an announcement “containing inside information” would come soon.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: An unfinished residential development by China Evergrande Group in Suzhou, Jiangsu Province, in October.

item.title: In the Tinderbox of Bosnia, a Serb Nationalist Lights a Match
item.description: Bosnia’s fragile multiethnic government is facing its greatest crisis since the Balkan wars. The Serb nationalist leader, Milorad Dodik, is threatening to tear the country apart.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A monument in Prijedor, Bosnia, commemorating Bosnian Serb soldiers killed in the 1990s. Many Serbs like Milorad Dodik deny war crimes committed by ethnic kin and see themselves as victims.

item.title: South Africa Parliament Is 'Gutted' by Large Fire
item.description: Officials warned that the damage to the buildings would be extensive. A man was arrested on Sunday morning inside the parliamentary complex, Parliament’s spokesman said.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: Smoke rising above the National Assembly on Sunday in Cape Town.

item.title: A Spanish Mystery: Is a ‘Masked Restorer’ to Blame for a Church’s Botched Repair?
item.description: Yet another imprudent fix in a land plagued by vigilante handymen led to angry calls to find the culprit — and to a soul-searching question: Does Spain just have too much history in need of upkeep?
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Casey
item.media:credit: Ben Roberts for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Church of Santa María del Castillo in the Spanish village of Castronuño was built around 1250.

item.title: China Moves to Overhaul Protections for Women’s Rights, Sort Of
item.description: The proposed revisions to a women’s rights law would be the first major changes in nearly 20 years. But many women are skeptical that real progress will follow.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: Supporters of Zhou Xiaoxuan in Beijing. Ms. Zhou, a prominent voice in China’s #MeToo movement, doubts the draft laws will change much. “This is probably still a very long, hard road,” she said.

item.title: Venice to Replace Glass on Santiago Calatrava's Slippery Bridge
item.description: The city will replace the glass on Santiago Calatrava’s footbridge across the Grand Canal with stone after too many pedestrians fell.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Francesca Volpi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ponte della Costituzione was meant to symbolize Venice’s embrace of modernity, but it has become better known for tumbles and slips.

item.title: South Korea Says Unknown Person Crossed DMZ Into North
item.description: The breach at the Demilitarized Zone went unnoticed for hours, the South Korean military said. There was no immediate response from North Korea.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Soldiers in 2019 at the Demilitarized Zone in Gangwon Province in South Korea.

item.title: Reason for Hope
item.description: We look back on the pandemic — and ahead to its next phases — with a handful of charts.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt and Ashley Wu
item.media:credit: Gabby Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Entering Times Square on New Year's Eve.

item.title: Celebrating the ‘Great Night of Shiva’ in Kathmandu
item.description: Every year, thousands of celebrants gather at a temple complex in Nepal’s capital in honor of Shiva, one of Hinduism’s most revered gods.
item.dc:creator: Shelby Tauber
item.media:description: The temple complex of Pashupatinath, on the banks of the Bagmati River.

item.title: Richard Leakey, Kenyan Fossil Hunter and Conservationist, Dies at 77
item.description: His discoveries of ancient human skulls and skeletons, including the famed “Turkana Boy,” helped cement Africa’s standing as the cradle of humanity.
item.dc:creator: Alyssa Lukpat and Christine Chung
item.category: State University of New York at Stony Brook
item.media:description: Richard Leakey in 1977 with two crucial skull discoveries — Australopithecus, left, and “1470,” Homo habilis.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: A crisis in Bosnia.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic and Whet Moser

item.title: U.S. Defense Secretary Tests Positive for Coronavirus
item.description: Lloyd J. Austin III stressed that his fully vaccinated status — including a booster received in early October — was to thank for his mild symptoms.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin said his symptoms were mild and that he would work from home for the next five days.

item.title: Sudan’s Prime Minister, Abdalla Hamdok, Resigns
item.description: Mr. Hamdok was restored to power a month ago after being deposed in a coup, but he was never able to gain control of the fractious country.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: A protest in Khartoum, Sudan’s capital, on Sunday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: South Africa’s Parliament Burns
item.description: Plus a breach in the DMZ and posturing about women’s rights in China.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Smoke billowed from the National Assembly building in Cape Town where a fire broke out in the early hours of the morning on Sunday.

item.title: Wellness vacations go beyond massages and diet tips during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Concepción de León

item.title: Governor: Maryland Prepares for 'Terrible Point' in Covid Crisis
item.description: Gov. Larry Hogan said the state was trying to staff hospitals through a variety of measures.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: Gov. Larry Hogan of Maryland in Annapolis in August.

item.title: Americans are bracing for the return to school and work.
item.dc:creator: Audra D. S. Burch, Stephanie Saul, Edgar Sandoval and Mitch Smith
item.media:credit: Andrea Ellen Reed for The New York Times
item.media:description: School officials are reconsidering whether to reopen classrooms amid a nationwide surge in Covid cases.

item.title: New York reports 85,000 cases in a day, another record, as surge shows no sign of slowing.
item.dc:creator: Louis Lucero II
item.media:credit: Jose A. Alvarado Jr. for The New York Times
item.media:description: Crowds gathered in Times Square in Manhattan on New Year’s Eve. The state reported a record number of new cases on Saturday.

item.title: A crew outbreak halts a German New Year’s cruise in Lisbon.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder
item.media:description: The cruise ship AIDAnova in the port of Lisbon on Saturday. The ship had been making a short stop but was held at the port after more than 50 crew members tested positive.

item.title: A Vatican Library Shortens the Distance Between Its Works and Its Scholars
item.description: Rare books in Rome are going online thanks to a German copier, a Long Island scanning firm and a New York software company.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Rev. David Nazar, the rector of the Pontifical Oriental Institute. The collaboration to digitize its books reminded him of a “Mickey Rooney film.”

item.title: New Year’s Day charity swims are being canceled around the world.
item.dc:creator: Alyssa Lukpat
item.media:description: Last year’s Loony Dook New Year’s Eve cold water swim in Edinburgh. That swim, like many other such New Year’s events, will not take place on Saturday because of surging coronavirus cases.

item.title: Desmond Tutu Funeral: South Africa Bids Farewell
item.description: The archbishop and Nobel laureate left plans for an unostentatious ceremony, which were stripped back further under Covid restrictions.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Clergy members carrying the coffin of Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu on Saturday after his funeral service at St. George’s Cathedral in Cape Town.

item.title: At Least 12 Die in Stampede at a Hindu Shrine in Kashmir
item.description: Thousands of devotees were visiting the Mata Vaishno Devi shrine to mark the beginning of the year.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:credit: NNIS, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Devotees at the Mata Vaishno Devi shrine in Katra, near Jammu, on Saturday.

item.title: Memorable Canada Stories in 2021
item.description: From the discovery of Indigenous graves in British Columbia to a faux Florida retirement community in Quebec, two Times Canada correspondents recall some of the standout stories of the year.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sections of Merritt, British Columbia, were washed out by the flooding in November.

item.title: In Turkey, an Exhibit Meant to Highlight Kurdish Suffering Provoked a Furor
item.description: A recent art show in a major Kurdish city in Turkey aimed to uplift a region crushed by years of conflict. It ended up serving as a reminder of how toxic the subject of Kurds remains in Turkey.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: The uproar over the exhibition by Ahmet Gunestekin, a Turkish Kurdish artist, was less about the quality of the art and more a reflection of how polarized Turkey has become under President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.

item.title: Setting New Year's Resolutions? Start With These Words of Wisdom
item.description: Let their stories be your inspiration as you set resolutions for 2022.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Reddy
item.media:credit: Aubrey Trinnaman for The New York Times

item.title: The New Political Cry in South Korea: ‘Out With Man Haters’
item.description: After slow gains in women’s rights, the country is facing a type of political correctness enforced by young men angry at feminists, saying they undermine opportunity.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Woohae Cho for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bae In-kyu, the head of Man on Solidarity, one of South Korea’s most active anti-feminist groups, leading a rally in Seoul last month. “Feminists are a social evil,” he has said.

item.title: Kim Jong-un’s New Year Resolution: More Food for North Korea
item.description: At a party meeting, Mr. Kim made little mention of the United States or South Korea. Instead, he promised to “completely solve the food problem.”
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency via KNS, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un, center, in a photograph released on Saturday by North Korean state media. He has been in power for 10 years.

item.title: Documents Reveal Flaws in Pentagon Dismissals of Civilian Casualty Claims in Iraq and Syria
item.description: A Times investigation found inconsistent approaches to assessing claims of civilians killed by coalition forces — including failures to conduct simple internet searches.
item.dc:creator: Azmat Khan, Haley Willis, Christoph Koettl, Christiaan Triebert and Lila Hassan
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: The actual site of a March 2016 coalition airstrike in Mosul, Iraq, was over a mile away from where the U.S. military said the strike had taken place.

item.title: Kirk Cousins Tests Positive for Covid-19
item.description: Cousins was placed on the team’s Covid-19 reserve list for at least five days, threatening Minnesota’s playoff chances.
item.dc:creator: Elena Bergeron
item.media:description: Kirk Cousins will miss the Vikings’ game against the Green Bay Packers, one of the best team in the league, this Sunday.

item.title: Quebec Government Faces Backlash Over New Year’s Eve Curfew
item.description: Residents who leave their homes past 10 p.m. could face fines of up to $4,750.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai and Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: Downtown Montreal in January, after the first curfew was imposed in Quebec to help slow the spread of Covid-19.

item.title: In New Year's Speech, Olaf Scholz, Germany's New Leader, Focuses on Covid
item.description: Olaf Scholz, who replaced Angela Merkel as chancellor about three weeks ago, gave the traditional New Year’s Eve address for the first time and called for unity and vaccinations.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: “One thing is clear: The next few days and weeks will also be dominated by corona,” said Olaf Scholz in his first New Year’s Eve speech as Germany’s chancellor.

item.title: Sergey V. Lavrov Accused NATO of Stoking Ukraine Conflict
item.description: Sergey V. Lavrov accused the United States and its allies of stoking a conflict in the country’s east in comments that contrasted with a more positive tone coming from Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Sergey V. Lavrov, Russia’s foreign minister, in Moscow in November.

item.title: U.K. Report Finds People With Omicron Are Less Likely to Need Hospitalization
item.description: The findings represent some of the largest sets of real-world data to be released since the highly contagious variant was first discovered.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Adeel Hassan
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: People walking in Covent Garden in London on Wednesday as the United Kingdom experienced a sharp rise in Covid-19 cases.

item.title: Once a Janitor, Now the Bar Mitzvah Photography King of Montreal
item.description: With a touch of chutzpah and “a little help from God,” Braulio Rocha, a Roman Catholic Portuguese immigrant, traded in his mop for a camera.
item.media:credit: Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Braulio Rocha showing bar mitzvah photographs to the Rosen family children at a Montreal synagogue.

item.title: Why Did Uganda Send Troops Into Congo?
item.description: The Ugandan government says it is targeting rebels it accuses of terrorist attacks in Kampala. Many Congolese fear the incursion is cover for yet another plundering of their country.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Sebastien Kitsa Musayi/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Ugandan soldiers in Mukakati, Congo, this month. Uganda says it is trying to root out fighters from the Allied Democratic Forces rebel group.

item.title: Asma Khader, Fighter for Women’s Rights in Jordan, Dies at 69
item.description: A respected lawyer, she focused on the victims of domestic violence and also worked hard to change discriminatory laws.
item.dc:creator: Rana F. Sweis
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Asma Khader in 2019. She campaigned for the rights of women in Jordan, fighting to protect the victims of domestic violence and to limit the marriages of girls under 18.

item.title: In Remembering Tutu, South Africa Reckons With Lasting Challenges
item.description: Archbishop Desmond Tutu’s death has reignited a public conversation about the state of the country’s reconciliation process and its democracy.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: A memorial service for Archbishop Desmond Tutu at St Mary’s Cathedral in Johannesburg on Thursday.

item.title: Paris Reimposes Outdoor Mask Mandate as Omicron Soars
item.description: With more than 2,000 coronavirus cases per 100,000 people, the capital has become the center of France’s spreading Omicron outbreak.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Paris on Thursday. An outdoor mask mandate began in the capital on Friday, and no end date for it was given.

item.title: Happy New Year
item.description: We wish you a happy and healthy 2022. Below, a look at some unusual New Year’s Eves.
item.dc:creator: Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:description: New Year’s Eve in Times Square ringing in 1973.

item.title: What Default? With Confetti and Fanfare, Evergrande Says It’s Ready to Build.
item.description: Weeks after signaling it could no longer go on, the troubled Chinese property developer has pledged to start paying its workers and completing projects again. Buyers are skeptical.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Joy Dong
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Evergrande Mansions construction site in Dongguan, China.

item.title: Is That a Burning Bush? Is This Mt. Sinai? Solstice Bolsters a Claim
item.description: On the year’s shortest day, hundreds of Israelis ventured deep into the desert to witness a strange natural phenomenon atop an ancient pilgrimage site that some argue is where God spoke to Moses.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: The “Burning Bush” phenomenon, occurring on the winter solstice, at Mount Karkom in the Negev Desert in southern Israel.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: A call between Biden and Putin.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden disembarking Marine One.

item.title: Omicron Strains France’s Social Contract on Covid
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron won people over by promising normalcy if they followed Covid advice. Now Omicron has raised questions about whether he, or any leader, can deliver on that.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi, Constant Méheut and Léontine Gallois
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times

item.title: Suspect in Deadly Arson Fire in Osaka, Japan, Dies in Hospital
item.description: The suspect, a 61-year-old man, had been hospitalized for smoke inhalation since the Dec. 17 fire at a psychiatric clinic, which killed 25 other people.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley
item.media:description: Mourners at the scene of the Dec. 17 fire in downtown Osaka, two days after the blaze.

item.title: Putin Warns Biden of ‘Complete Rupture’ of U.S.-Russia Relationship Over Ukraine
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia spoke with President Biden for 50 minutes about the escalating crisis with Ukraine, but his intentions remained unclear.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden spoke with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia by phone on Thursday regarding the situation at the Ukrainian border, where Russia has massed about 100,000 troops.

item.title: South Africa Says It Has Passed Its Fourth Wave of Cases
item.description: Case counts are down by 30 percent in the last week, researchers in the country said.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:description: A beach in Cape Town, South Africa. Data suggests that the country’s Omicron wave has passed.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Biden and Putin discuss Ukraine
item.description: Putin requested the call amid tensions on Ukrainian border.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: Russian service members performed tactical combat exercises in the Rostov region of Russian, near the Ukranian border last week.

item.title: Israel Approves 4th Dose of Covid Vaccine for Some
item.description: The Ministry of Health said it was waiting for more data from Israel and abroad before approving any broader rollout of fourth shots.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Prof. Jacov Lavee receiving a fourth dose of Pfizer’s Covid vaccine as part of a trial that began Monday at an Israeli hospital.

item.title: Deaths in 2021: Headline Names Against the Backdrop of Pandemic
item.description: Aaron, Sondheim, Dole and Didion. But the loss of Colin Powell from the virus spoke most directly to the moment the world is in.
item.dc:creator: William McDonald
item.media:credit: Didion: Henry Clarke/Condé Nast/Shutterstock; Powell: Kenneth Lambert/AP; Madden: via Associated Press; Sondheim: Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times; Tyson: Kevin Winter/Getty Images; Allard: Jens Schwarz/laif/Redux

item.title: UK, With Surging Covid-19 Cases, is On '‘War Footing’ Against Virus
item.description: With cases surging and straining health care and other services, Britain’s challenges foreshadow the impact of the Omicron variant in other countries.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: A temporary field hospital is being erected on the grounds of St. George’s Hospital in south London, as the number of daily coronavirus cases surges in Britain.
